{{RefImprove|date=April 2018}}{{advert|date=February 2012}} [[File:Logo_red_large.jpg|thumb|upright|London Design Festival logo]]
The '''London Design Festival (LDF)''' is a citywide design event that takes place over nine days every September. Conceived by [[Sir John Sorrell]] and Ben Evans in 2003, the concept was to create an annual event to promote the city’s creativity, drawing in the country's thinkers, practitioners, retailers and educators to a deliver a diverse celebration of design.
== About == London Design Festival's vision is to celebrate and promote London as the design capital of the world. The Festival programme is made up of over 400 events and exhibitions staged by over 300 partner organisations across the design spectrum and from around the world. The Festival also commissions its own projects and produces a Guide every year, containing information about all activity.
Festival audiences are significant, with an estimated direct audience of over 450,000 people from over 75 countries in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Facts and Figures from the London Design Festival 2015|url=http://us1.campaign-archive2.com/?u=4a7adb928b5af626420a06774&id=61ec7d2d21|website=London Design Festival|publisher=London Design Festival}}</ref>
Over 2,000 international design businesses took part in the 2017 London Design Festival including exhibitors at five Design Destinations: 100% Design, Decorex International, designjunction, Focus/18, and [[London Design Fair]] (previously known as ''Tent London'').
In 2018 ten Design Districts will participate in the Festival - Bankside, Brompton, Clerkenwell, Fitzrovia, Marylebone, Mayfair, Pimlico Road, Regent St & St James's, Shoreditch and West Kensington - offering a programme of events, [[exhibitions]], talks and tours.
The V&A Museum is the official residency and hub of the Festival, with 2018 seeing the celebration of 10 years in partnership together.
== Location == [[File:You Know You Cannot See Yourself So Well As By Reflection.png|thumb|300px|'You Know You Cannot See Yourself So Well As By Reflection' at the V&A, 2015.]] Since 2009 the [[Victoria & Albert Museum]] has acted as the central Hub location for the London Design Festival.
In 2017, London Design Festival helped drive a total of 173,250 visits to the V&A over the Festival period with 22% of those surveyed saying they had never visited the museum before and were driven there by the Festival. Flynn Talbot’s Reflection Room and Ross Lovegrove’s Transmission installations were particularly popular.
For the nine days of the Festival, visitors to the V&A will explore a range of special displays and installations throughout the museum, complemented by an extensive programme of events, daily tours, and workshops from Global Design Forum, which in 2017 drew 45 speakers from 13 countries, and 2,800 visitors.
Celebrating ten years with the V&A as the official London Design Festival hub, this unique collaboration sees iconic spaces within the Museum transformed each year by an extraordinary collection of specially-commissioned installations and displays by international contemporary designers.
== London Design Festival Landmark Projects and Commissioning Programme== [[File:A Bullet from a Shooting Star, by Alex Chinneck.png|thumb|300px|'A Bullet from a Shooting Star' installation at Greenwich Peninsula, 2015.]]
Since 2007, London Design Festival has been commissioning leading [[designers]] and [[architects]] to create installations in [[London|London’s]] [[public spaces]] during the Festival. Locations for these installations have included [[Trafalgar Square]], [[Southbank Centre|the Southbank Centre]], the [[Victoria and Albert Museum|V&A]], [[Somerset House]], [[Covent Garden]], [[St Paul's Cathedral]] and [[Greenwich Peninsula]].
* 2007 – "Urban Nebula", [[Zaha Hadid]]; "Prototile", [[Amanda Levete]] * 2008 – "Sclera", [[David Adjaye]]; "Portrait," Fredrickson Stallard * 2009 – "Supercell", [[Marc Newson]]; "Paper Tower", [[Shigeru Ban]]; "Tournament", Jaime Hayón * 2010 – "Framed", Stuart Haygarth; "Drop", Paul Cocksedge; "Outrace", Kram/Weisshaar; "Blow & Roll", Oskar Zieta; "Vermiculated Ashlar", Max Lamb * 2011 – "Perspectives", John Pawson; "Textile Field", [[Ronan & Erwan Bouroullec]]; "Two Lines", "David Chipperfield"; "Timber Wave", AL_A * 2012 – "BE OPEN Sound Portal", [[BE OPEN Foundation]]; "Bench Years", Various Designers; "Prism", Keiichi Matsuda; "Mimicry Chairs", [[Nendo]] * 2013 – “Endless Stair”, Alex de Rijke * 2014 – “A Place Called Home”, Airbnb; “Double Space for [[BMW]] – Precision & Poetry in Motion” [[BarberOsgerby|Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby]] * 2015 – “A Bullet From A Shooting Star”, [[Alex Chinneck]]; “You Know You Cannot See Yourself So Well As By Reflection”, [[Frida Escobedo]]; “The Ogham Wall”, Grafton Architects & Graphic Relief; “Mise-En-Abyme”, Laetitia De Allegri & Matteo Fogale; “Curiosity Cloud”, Mischer’Traxler; “Zotem”, Kim Thomé; “Works in Wood”, Robin Day Foundation; “The Cloakroom”, Faye Toogood * 2016 – "The Smile", Alison Brooks; "Forests", Asif Khan with MINI LIVING; "Foil", Benjamin Hubert, "The Green Room", Glithero; "Beloved", Tabanlioglu; "Liquid Marble", Mathieu Lehanneur * 2017 – "Villa Walala", Camille Walala; "Urban Cabin", Sam Jacob Studio with MINI LIVING; "Reflection Room", Flynn Talbot; "Transmission", Ross Lovegrove
== Awards == [[File:British Land Celebration of Design Winners 2015.png|thumb|right|300px|Winners of the British Land Celebration of Design 2015.]] Each year a Jury composed of established designers, industry commentators and previous winners choose recipients of ''The [[British Land]] Celebration of Design'' across four categories. Winners are chosen from a wide range of design disciplines and awards for their exceptional contribution to their field.
The London Design Medal categories include: * Panerai London Design Medal * Design Innovation Medal * Emerging Talent Medal * Lifetime Achievement Medal
“While there are no shortage of design awards, we wanted to do it differently: not just a big dinner that everyone has to buy tables for,” says Festival Director Ben Evans. “So we took the Nobel Prize route – there’s no shortlist, just a winner. So that means there’s no losers either.”<ref>{{cite web|last1=Evans|first1=Ben|title=British Land Celebration of Design|url=http://www.londondesignfestival.com/british-land-celebration-of-design-2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160317051440/http://www.londondesignfestival.com/british-land-celebration-of-design-2015|archivedate=2016-03-17|df=}}</ref>
The London Design Medal is designed each year by jewellery designer Hannah Martin. The medals feature a London bird, the Cockney Sparrow, in flight. Previous winners include [[Ken Adam|Sir Ken Adam]], [[Peter Saville (graphic designer)|Peter Saville]], [[Marc Newson]], [[Paul Smith (fashion designer)|Sir Paul Smith]], Dame [[Zaha Hadid]], [[Thomas Heatherwick]], [[Sir Terence Conran]] and [[Ron Arad (industrial designer)|Ron Arad.]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.londondesignfestival.com London Design Festival official website]
[[Category:Festivals in London|Design Festival]] [[Category:British design exhibitions]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2003]] [[Category:Design events]]

{{Infobox song contest |name = Melodifestivalen |year = 2009 |logo = Melodifestivalen 2009.jpg |final = 14 March 2009 |semi = 7 February 2009
14 February 2009
21 February 2009
28 February 2009 |second = 7 March 2009 |presenters = [[Petra Mede]] |director = |venue = [[Ericsson Globe|Globe Arena]], [[Stockholm]], Sweden |winner = "[[La voix (song)|La voix]]" by [[Malena Ernman]] |vote = 50% Jury, 50% SMS and telephone voting
12 juries (11 regional juries and one international jury) give 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 and 12 points to their seven favourite songs.
People can vote by televote or SMS. Televoting gives 12, 24, 48, 72, 96, 120 and 144 points to the seven most popular songs. |entries = 32: 8 in each semi-final; 11 in the final (2 from each semi-final, 2 from the Second Chance round, and 1 selected by the international jury) |opening = |interval = Pihlman & Pål }} '''Melodifestivalen 2009''' was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] song contest held between February and March 2009. It was the selection for the 49th song to represent [[Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest]], and was the 48th edition of [[Melodifestivalen]]. Five semi-finals were held in the Swedish cities of [[Gothenburg]], [[Skellefteå]], [[Leksand]] and [[Malmö]], with [[Norrköping]] hosting the final ''Andra Chansen'' (Second Chance) round. After the five semi-finals 11 songs had qualified to the final of the contest, contested in the Swedish capital of [[Stockholm]], at the [[Ericsson Globe|Globe Arena]]. After the voting of 12 juries and a public televote had been revealed, the final winner was [[opera]] singer [[Malena Ernman]] with pop/opera song "[[La voix (song)|La voix]]", which received top marks from the public televote, despite only placing eighth after the votes of the 12 juries. The 2009 edition of Melodifestivalen implemented a number of new rules which changed the dynamics of the contest, including an increase in the number of people allowed on stage, the allowance of pre-recorded backing vocals, and a new international jury who selected an eleventh finalist, and voted in the final. ==Rules== {{See also|History of Melodifestivalen|Voting at Melodifestivalen}} The current rules for Melodifestivalen were first implemented in [[Melodifestivalen 2002|2002]] – the format consists of five semi-finals held every year: the first four semi-finals each consist of eight songs, in which the top two songs directly qualify to the final of the contest, while the third and fourth-placed songs qualify to the final semi-final, the ''Andra Chansen'' (Second Chance) round. Eight songs compete in the Second Chance round, competing in a knock-out format until two songs are left, which qualify to the final. These songs are chosen by a public televote held on the night of the contest. The final consisted of 10 songs, who are awarded marks by 11 regional juries of Sweden, alongside televoting, with each constituting 50% of the total result.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1240|title=Swedish national final to change!|last=Schacht|first=Andreas|date=2008-08-26|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2009-07-10}} 28 songs are selected from a public call for songs by SVT. These are chosen from a large number of entries, with over 3000 entries being received by SVT in past contests. These songs are reduced by the Swedish Music Publishers Association (''Svenska musikförläggareföreningen''; SMFF), who reduce this large number to around 1200 entries.{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=3969 |title=One month left for Melodifestivalen entries |last=Fisher |first=Luke |date=2008-08-25 |publisher=''Oikotimes'' |accessdate=2008-08-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301050602/http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=3969 |archivedate=2009-03-01 |df= }} A sixteen-person jury reduce this number once again to the final 28 competing songs. These 28 songs are then joined by compositions by four songwriters invited by SVT, who each submit a song into the competition. For the 2009 contest a number of changes were implemented to this format: the first four semi-finals now include a duel format, with the top four songs competing against each other for a place in the final - the 1st and 4th-placed songs and the 2nd and 3rd-placed songs battled against each other, with the winning songs, as decided by another public televote, qualifying to the final, while the losing songs take part in the Second Chance round.{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.104594/1.1416221/regler_-_nytt_for_i_ar |title=Regler - nytt för i år |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-07-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090526215927/http://svt.se/2.104594/1.1416221/regler_-_nytt_for_i_ar |archivedate=2009-05-26 |df= }} For the 2009 contest a maximum of eight people were allowed on stage, an increase from the previous maximum of six. As well as this pre-recorded backing vocals were now allowed to be included on the songs' backing tracks, however the main vocals were still required to be performed on stage. This year also marked the introduction of an "international jury". The jury consists of 12 members, who all work within the music industry, with many involved in Eurovision.{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.104594/1.1444596/internationella_juryn_-_ny_for_i_ar |title=Internationella juryn - ny för i år |date=2009-02-14 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |accessdate=2009-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090525185929/http://svt.se/2.104594/1.1444596/internationella_juryn_-_ny_for_i_ar |archivedate=2009-05-25 |df= }} The international jury selected one song from each semi-final that did not qualify to the final, focusing their decision on their suitability for Eurovision. After the Second Chance round had finished, the jury selected their preferred song from the remaining entries, which qualified to the final, becoming the 11th finalist. The international jury also voted during the final of the contest, becoming the 12th jury, alongside the 11 regional juries of Sweden. ==Details== [[File:Malmö Arena.JPG|230px|thumb|right|The newly constructed [[Malmö Arena]] hosted the fourth semi-final.]] [[File:Globen Stockholm February 2007.jpg|230px|thumb|right|Stockholm's [[Ericsson Globe|Globen]], the venue for the final of Melodifestivalen 2009.]] On 11 September 2008 the six cities that were to host Melodifestivlan 2009 were announced: the first semi-final would be held in Sweden's second city, [[Gothenburg]] – at the [[Scandinavium]]; this was followed by semi-finals in the [[Skellefteå]] [[Skellefteå Kraft Arena|Kraft Arena]], the [[Ejendals Arena]] in the small town of [[Leksand]], and in the newly constructed [[Malmö Arena]] in [[Malmö]]. The Second Chance round was in the [[Himmelstalundshallen]] in [[Norrköping]], while the grand final would once again be held at [[Ericsson Globe|Globen]] in [[Stockholm]].{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1243763/har_ar_staderna_2009_-_pressmeddelande?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1243763 |title=HÄR ÄR STÄDERNA 2009 - pressmeddelande |date=2008-09-11 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |accessdate=2008-09-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613002700/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1243763/har_ar_staderna_2009_-_pressmeddelande?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1243763 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} The dates for the contest were also announced, with the first semi-final being held on 7 February, leading up to the final on 14 March 2009 over six weeks. After two years of hosting the contest, it was announced that [[Kristian Luuk]] would not be hosting the 2009 edition of Melodifestivalen.{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1272582/ingen_luuk_pa_melodifestivalen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1272582 |title=Ingen Luuk på Melodifestivalen |date=2008-10-09 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-07-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613003131/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1272582/ingen_luuk_pa_melodifestivalen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1272582 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} He was replaced by comedian [[Petra Mede]], who was announced at the new host in a press conference by SVT on 18 December.{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1351729/pressmeddelande_petra_mede_ar_programledare_for_melodifestivalen_2009?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1351729 |title=Petra Mede är programledare för Melodifestivalen 2009 |date=2008-12-18 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2008-12-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613003446/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1351729/pressmeddelande_petra_mede_ar_programledare_for_melodifestivalen_2009?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1351729 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12733|title=Petra Mede to host Melodifestivalen|last=Viniker|first=Barry|date=2008-12-18|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2009-07-12}} ===Schedule=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date !! City !! Venue !! Heat |- | 7 February || [[Gothenburg]] || [[Scandinavium]] || Semi-final 1 |- | 14 February || [[Skellefteå]] || [[Skellefteå Kraft Arena|Kraft Arena]] || Semi-final 2 |- | 21 February || [[Leksand]] || [[Ejendals Arena]] || Semi-final 3 |- | 28 February || [[Malmö]] || [[Malmö Arena]] || Semi-final 4 |- | 7 March || [[Norrköping]] || [[Himmelstalundshallen]] || Second Chance |- | 14 March || [[Stockholm]] || [[Ericsson Globe|Globen]] || Final |} ===Visual design=== [[File:StageMelodifestivalen2009.jpg|left|thumb|230px|The stage of the contest]] The logo for the Contest, the now-familiar five spotlights, has not been altered since its interception in 2002, and remained in use for the 2009 Contest. The first details of the stage for this year's contest were released on 29 January 2009, a week before the first semi-final in Gothenburg. The first plans of the stage were made during the summer of 2008 and was, for the third time, designed by [[Viktor Brattström]], with the intention to provide a feeling of endlessness: "The audience will get the feeling of not knowing where the stage starts or ends, not knowing what's coming up around the corner".{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13075|title=Sweden: Melodifestivalen - Fantasy and movement|last=Viniker|first=Barry|date=2009-01-29|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2008-01-29}}{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=79613&a=1424444&lid=puff_1424493&lpos=lasMer |title=Det blir extravaganza i år |date=2009-01-29 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-01-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201135905/http://svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=79613&a=1424444&lid=puff_1424493&lpos=lasMer |archivedate=2009-02-01 |df= }} The green room, where the artists rested after their performances, was altered from previous contests. Instead of competing artists and composers sitting together at tables, artists sat together on sofas beside the stage, while composers sat together in the front rows of the audience. ==Entries== A record-breaking 3,440 songs were submitted to the competition, with only 28 proceeding to the next round.{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1258966/nytt_bidragsrekord_for_melodifestivalen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1258966 |title=Nytt bidragsrekord för Melodifestivalen |date=2008-09-26 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2008-09-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613003700/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1258966/nytt_bidragsrekord_for_melodifestivalen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1258966 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1378|title=3440 songs entered for Melodifestivalen!|last=Schacht|first=Andreas|date=2008-09-26|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2008-09-26}} The final 28 songs chosen to compete in the semi-finals were released by SVT on 14 October, along with the names of their authors.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12375 |title=28 song titles and authors revealed |last=Repo |first=Juha |date=2008-10-14 |publisher=ESCToday |accessdate=2008-10-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015100659/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12375 |archivedate=2008-10-15 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1399|title=Swedish TV reveals songs|last=Schacht|first=Andreas|date=2008-10-14|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2008-10-14}}{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1278176/28_bidrag_och_upphovsman_klara?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1278176 |title=28 bidrag och upphovsmän klara |date=2008-10-14 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2008-10-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613003740/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1278176/28_bidrag_och_upphovsman_klara?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1278176 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} The names of the performers were held back, and were released in groups over the following weeks. However this did not stop speculation on who would perform certain songs in the semi-final.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12385|title=Melodifestialen names: Wait a little longer|last=Floras|first=Stella|date=2008-10-16|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2008-10-16}} The first eight participants were revealed on 18 November 2009: they included former participants [[Alcazar (band)|Alcazar]], [[BWO (band)|BWO]], [[Måns Zelmerlöw]], [[Lasse Lindh]], [[Caroline af Ugglas]] and [[Sarah Dawn Finer]], as well as debuting artists [[Emilia Rydberg|Emilia]] and [[Jennifer Brown (singer)|Jennifer Brown]].{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12530|title=The first eight Melodifestivalen singers|last=Viniker|first=Barry|date=2008-11-23|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2008-11-23}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1494|title=First 8 Melodifestivalen singers known|last=Schacht|first=Andreas|date=2008-11-23|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2008-11-23}} On 23 November, the tenth act was revealed by Melodifestivalen producer [[Christer Björkman]] on the reality TV show ''Dansbandkampen''. The Scotts, a participant on the show, was revealed to have been selected to compete in Melodifestivalen 2009 with "Jag tror på oss".{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12562|title=The Scotts make Swedish Eurovision bid|last=Viniker|first=Barry|date=2008-11-24|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2008-11-24}}{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1322796/scotts_tavlar_i_melodifestivalen_2009?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1322796 |title=Scotts tävlar i Melodifestivalen 2009 |date=2008-11-23 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2008-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613004251/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1322796/scotts_tavlar_i_melodifestivalen_2009?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1322796 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} SVT followed by releasing the next group of competing artists, all of whom had never competed in Melodifestivalen before: [[H.E.A.T]], [[Jonathan Fagerlund]], Maja Gullstrand, [[Mikael Rickfors]], [[Molly Sandén]], Next 3, and Rigo & The Topaz Sound feat. Red Fox were all announced to have been successful in their applying for Melodifestivalen.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1591|title=New names in Sweden|last=Schacht|first=Andreas|date=2008-11-25|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2008-11-25}}{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12566|title=Sweden: Seven debut artists for Melodifestivalen 2009|last=Roberg|first=Leif|date=2008-11-25|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2008-11-25}} Six more artists were revealed on 2 December by SVT's ''Culture News''{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12567 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924121324/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12567 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2015-09-24 |title=Second wildcard revealed tonight |last=Viniker |first=Barry |date=2008-11-26 |publisher=ESCToday |accessdate=2008-11-26 }} – [[Idol 2005|Idol]] winner [[Agnes Carlsson|Agnes]] was announced to be making her debut to Melodifestivalen after being disqualified in 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/6516 |title=Agnes Carlsson disqualified from MF |last=Viniker |first=Barry |date=2006-10-13 |publisher=ESCToday |accessdate=2006-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061116050949/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/6516 |archivedate=2006-11-16 |df= }} The remaining artists announced were all making their returns to Melodifestivalen, including [[Shirley Clamp]], [[Lili & Susie]], [[Amy Diamond]], [[Sofia (Swedish singer)|Sofia]] and [[Velvet (singer)|Velvet]].{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1605|title=New Swedish revelations|last=Schacht|first=Andreas|date=2008-12-02|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2008-12-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12618 |title=Six more names confirmed for Melodifestivalen |last=Repo |first=Juha |date=2008-12-06 |publisher=ESCToday |accessdate=2008-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203234134/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12618 |archivedate=2008-12-03 |df= }} A day before the next group of artists were released by SVT it had been rumoured that two former Eurovision participants would compete in a duet – [[Estonia]]'s [[Eurovision Song Contest 2002|2002]] participant [[Anna Sahlene|Sahlene]], and Norway's [[Eurovision Song Contest 2008|2008]] participant, and current host of Norway's equivalent of Melodifestivalen, [[Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest 2009|Melodi Grand Prix]], [[Maria Haukaas Storeng]].{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12652|title=Maria Haukaas Storeng to Eurovision again?|last=Viniker|first=Barry|date=2008-12-08|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2008-12-08}} The following day, on 9 December, SVT confirmed the news, and also announced the names of four more artists: [[Susanne Alfvengren]], the Thorleifs, [[Nina Söderquist]] and Cookies 'n Beans.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1621|title=Almost all Swedish singers known!|last=Schacht |first=Andreas|date=2008-12-09|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2008-12-09}}{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12659|title=Five more names in Eurovision race for Sweden|last=Viniker|first=Barry|date=2008-12-09|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2008-12-09}} The final non-wild card entry to be announced was revealed on 16 December, with the [[Star Pilots]] performing "Higher" in the contest.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12703|title=E.M.D. the last Melodifestivalen wildcard|last=Floras|first=Stella|date=2008-12-16|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2008-12-16}} ===Wild cards=== The wild card (''joker'') system was introduced in 2004 to diversify the music featured in the competition.[http://svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=64781&lid=puff_759306&lpos=extra_0 Melodifestivalen 2007—FAQ in English] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226155242/http://svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=64781&lid=puff_759306&lpos=extra_0 |date=2009-02-26 }}. SVT.se. Retrieved on 1 May 2007. Four artists, one in each semifinal, are invited by SVT to enter a song of their choice into the competition, provided it does not breach the rules. In a change from previous years, the names of the wild card entries were released alongside the submitted entries instead of the usual method of releasing the wild cards after the other 28 entries.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12531 |title=Melodifestivalen: 1st wildcard announced tomorrow |last=Viniker |first=Barry |date=2008-11-18 |publisher=ESCToday |accessdate=2008-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090109181856/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12531 |archivedate=2009-01-09 |df= }} The first wild card entry was released on 19 November, with Melodifestivalen producer [[Christer Björkman]], Jennifer Brown and Måns Zelmerlöw featuring on ''Godmorgon Sverige''. They revealed that Finnish-Swedish singer [[Markoolio]] would enter Melodifestivalen with the song "Kärlekssång från mig".{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1518|title=Markoolio first wildcard in Sweden|last=Schacht|first=Andreas|date=2008-11-19|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2008-11-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12534|title=Markoolio is Melodifestivalen first wildcard|last=Floras|first=Stella|date=2008-11-19|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2008-11-19}} The second wild card entry was announced on 26 November by SVT – opera singer [[Malena Ernman]] was confirmed to be participating in this year's contest with "La voix", composed by herself and [[Fredrik Kempe]], who also composed last year's winning entry "[[Hero (Charlotte Perrelli song)|Hero]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1595|title=An opera diva for Sweden?|last=Schacht|first=Andreas|date=2008-11-26|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2008-11-26}} The third wild card was announced on 3 December, with [[Marie Serneholt]], formerly of [[A*Teens]], taking part with "Disconnect Me", written by Peter Boström and Tony Nilsson.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1609|title=Marie Serneholt gets wildcard in Sweden|last=Schacht|first=Andreas|date=2008-12-03|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2008-12-03}}{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1334387/tredje_jokern_avslojad?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1334387 |title=Tredje jokern avslöjad! |date=2008-12-03 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2008-12-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613004344/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1334387/tredje_jokern_avslojad?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1334387 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} The final wild card entry was revealed on 16 December – boyband [[E.M.D.]], consisting of [[Erik Segerstedt]], [[Mattias Andréasson]] and [[Danny Saucedo]] (all of them former [[Idol (Sweden)|Idol]] competitors) were announced as the last competitor, performing "Baby Goodbye", written by the band members and Oscar Görres.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1636|title=Sweden revealed last wildcard!|last=Siim|first=Jarmo|date=2008-12-16|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2008-12-16}}{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1349079/e_m_d_fjarde_jokern_i_melodifestivalen_2009?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1349079 |title=E.M.D. fjärde jokern i Melodifestivalen 2009 |date=2008-12-16 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-07-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613004357/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1349079/e_m_d_fjarde_jokern_i_melodifestivalen_2009?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1349079 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} '''Wild card entries''' {| class="wikitable" |- ! Artist !! Song
''(English translation)'' !! Semi-final !! Result in semi-final |- | [[Marie Serneholt]] || "Disconnect Me" || Gothenburg || Out – 6th place |- | [[Markoolio]] || "Kärlekssång från mig"
''(Love song from me)'' || Skellefteå || Out – 6th place |- | [[E.M.D.]] || "[[Baby Goodbye (E.M.D. song)|Baby Goodbye]]" || Leksand || '''''Final''''' – 1st place |- | [[Malena Ernman]] || "[[La voix]]" || Malmö || '''''Final''''' – 1st place |- |} ==Semi-finals== Each of the 32 songs were sorted into one semi-final on 11 December, with 8 songs each competing in a semi-final (including one wild card).{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1626|title=More Melodifestivalen news!|last=Schacht|first=Andreas|date=2008-12-11|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2008-12-11}}{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1343540/vilken_melodifestivalartist_i_vilken_stad?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1343540 |title=Vilken Melodifestivalartist i vilken stad? |date=2008-12-11 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-07-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613004419/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1343540/vilken_melodifestivalartist_i_vilken_stad?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1343540 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} However the final running order for the semi-final was conducted on 15 January – [[Nina Söderquist]] would open the first semi-final with "Tick Tock", while wild card [[Malena Ernman]] would close the final semi-final with "La voix".{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12911|title=Melodifestivalen 2009: The running order|last=Viniker|first=Barry|date=2009-01-15|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2009-01-15}}{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1390536/forst_och_sist_-_se_startordningen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1390536 |title=Först och sist - se startordningen! |date=2009-01-15 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-07-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613004450/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1390536/forst_och_sist_-_se_startordningen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1390536 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1413182/deltavlingarna_-_arenor_och_artister?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1413182 |title=Deltävlingarna - arenor och artister |date=2009-01-21 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-07-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613004611/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1413182/deltavlingarna_-_arenor_och_artister?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1413182 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} The four semi-finals were held between 7 and 28 February, with the Second Chance round being held on 7 March. ===Semi-final 1=== The first semi-final was held on 7 February at the [[Scandinavium]] in [[Gothenburg]]. The show began with host [[Petra Mede]] introducing the eight competing acts, with a number of skits being shown with former winners [[Charlotte Perrelli]] and [[Martin Stenmarck]]. The first song on stage was [[Nina Söderquist]] with "Tick Tock", a powerful rock song. Söderquist performed in a black leather outfit, joined by four male backing dancers and two male backing singers, all in black. Fire was used frequently during the performance. Second on stage was [[Jonathan Fagerlund]], performing "[[Welcome to My Life (Jonathan Fagerlund song)|Welcome to My Life]]". Fagerlund, dressed in a grey top and jeans, was joined on stage by an all-female backing band for his performance of the light pop/rock song. Next on stage was [[Melodifestivalen 2004]] runner-up [[Shirley Clamp]], performing the first [[Swedish language]] song of the contest, "Med hjärtat fyllt av ljus" (With my heart full of light). Clamp performed the ballad alone on stage, dressed in a long blue dress. The stage was also bathed in blue light, and wind machines were later used in the performance. The fourth act on stage was [[dansband]] the Scotts, performing "Jag tror på oss" (I believe in us). The quartet, performing in black and silver suits, were joined by three female backing singers, dressed in short black dresses.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13187|title=Sweden: Melodifestivalen 2009 First Heat|last=Lewis|first=Daniel|date=2009-02-07|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2009-02-07}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5046 |title=Sweden: Live from Gothenburg, the first Melodifestivalen semifinal |last=Konstantopoulos |first=Fotis |date=2009-02-07 |publisher=''Oikotimes'' |accessdate=2009-02-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090211131637/http://oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5046 |archivedate=2009-02-11 |df= }}''Melodifestivalen 2009: Semi-final 1''. ''[[Sveriges Television]]'' (2009-02-07). Retrieved on 2009-02-07. The fifth act on stage was [[Emilia Rydberg|Emilia]], singing "[[You're My World (Emilia Rydberg song)|You're My World]]", an up-tempo pop song with jazz elements. Emilia was dressed in a sparkling gold dress, joined on stage by four female backing singers, a pianist, drummer and bassist, all dressed in [[Big band]] era inspired outfits. Pyrotechnics were later used towards the end of the song. Next on stage was twice third-placers [[Alcazar (band)|Alcazar]], composed of [[Andreas Lundstedt]], [[Therese Merkel|Tess Merkel]] and [[Lina Hedlund]]. Their song "[[Stay the Night (Alcazar song)|Stay the Night]]", a energetic disco song, began with violet light shining on the band members, dressed in pink and blue. The group were joined by three backing dancers, with dancing featured throughout the song by the trio. The penultimate song was [[Caroline af Ugglas]] with "Snälla snälla" (Please, please), an emotional ballad. Caroline, dressed in a short white dress with bright blue [[Wellington boot|wellies]], gave an emotional performance, with anger and frustration prominent. Last on stage was the semi-finals wild card entry, [[Marie Serneholt]] with "Disconnect Me". Serneholt performed the energetic pop song in a short white dress, joined by four male dancers, and later by two female backing singers, all in black. After the first round of televoting was conducted Marie Serneholt, Jonathan Fagerlund and Shirley Clamp were all eliminated from the competition after receiving the fewest votes. They were joined by Nina Söderquist, after she received the fewest votes in the second round of voting. All of the remaining four acts progressed to the duels.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13186|title=Sweden: First two acts chosen for the national final|last=Klier|first=Marcus|date=2009-02-07|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2009-02-07}}{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1436026/alcazar_och_emilia_till_globen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1436026 |title=Alcazar och Emilia till Globen |date=2009-02-07 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-02-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613004653/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1436026/alcazar_och_emilia_till_globen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1436026 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !rowspan="2"|# !rowspan="2"|Artist !rowspan="2"|Song

border-style: solid;border-color:black;"|  |- | height=6| |} A total of 3,294,000 watched the semi-final on SVT, with 721,334 votes cast during the semi-final, a record for the first semi-final of Melodifestivalen. Because of this, 1,396,108[[Swedish krona|kr]] was donated to SVT's charity appeal ''Radiohjälpen''.{{cite web|url=http://www.gylleneskor.se/artikel/naestan-33-miljoner-tv-tittare-sag-foersta-deltaevlingen|title=Nästan 3,3 miljoner tv-tittare såg första deltävlingen|last=Bolander|first=Mattias|date=2009-02-09|publisher=''Gyllenskor''|language=Swedish|accessdate=2009-07-13}} ===Semi-final 2=== The second semi-final was held at the [[Skellefteå Kraft Arena]] in [[Skellefteå]] on 14 February. [[File:Lili & Susie.JPG|thumb|157px|[[Lili & Susie]] performing "Show Me Heaven".]] The first act on stage was sisters [[Lili & Susie]] with "Show Me Heaven". The sisters performed the energetic pop song in white top and black trousers, and were joined on stage by a group of backing dancers/singers, all in black. Large white letters spelt out the title of the song on the backing LED screens, and pyrotechnics were used at the end of the song. Second on stage was [[Lasse Lindh]] och Bandet, performing "Jag ska slåss i dina kvarter!" (I'll be fighting in your neighbourhood!). Lindh performed the rock song with a backing band and a male backing singer in black. Next on stage was [[Jennifer Brown (singer)|Jennifer Brown]] with "Never Been Here Before", an emotional pop/rock song. Brown, dressed in a silver top and black trousers, was joined on stage by three male violinists, two male trombonists and a male guitarist, who also performed backing vocals. The fourth act on stage was rock band [[H.E.A.T]] with "1000 Miles". The group performed in black, while the stage was brightened by pulsating light.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13245|title=Sweden: Melodifestivalen 2009 Semi Final 2|last=Lewis|first=Daniel|date=2009-02-14|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2009-02-14}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5114 |title=Live from Skellefteå, report and results |last=van Tongeren |first=Mario |date=2009-02-14 |publisher=''Oikotimes'' |accessdate=2009-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090217185518/http://oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5114 |archivedate=2009-02-17 |df= }}''Melodifestivalen 2009: Semi-final 2''. ''[[Sveriges Television]]'' (2009-02-14). Retrieved on 2009-02-14. Fifth on stage was [[Markoolio]], performing "Kärlekssång från mig" (Love song from me), a comedic love ballad. Markoolio, dressed in a burgundy suit, was joined on stage by a pianist and a violinist, dressed in black. A man dressed as Elvis appeared from within the piano, dancing and skating on stage, before being set on fire by pyrotechnics at the climax at the song. He was extinguished at the end of the song. [[Amy Diamond]] performed next, singing "[[It's My Life (Amy Diamond song)|It's My Life]]". Diamond performed the pop song in a silver jumper, and was accompanied by six female backing dancers in black and pink. Her jumper was removed to reveal a white and black top with black leggings. Large images of diamonds were shown on the screens while blue light shone down on stage. [[Cookies 'N' Beans]] were the second last act to take the stage, singing "What If", an emotional country ballad. The trio performed alone on stage, dressed in black, blue and red dresses. A guitar solo opened the song before going into the emotional performance of the trio. The last song of the night was "[[Hope & Glory (song)|Hope & Glory]]", sung by [[Måns Zelmerlöw]], who previously came third in [[Melodifestivalen 2007|2007]]. The [[schlager]] song (with a boxing theme) was performed by Zelmerlöw in a black tuxedo, joined on stage by six female backing dancers/singers in black outfits. Markoolio, Jennifer Brown and Lasse Lindh were all eliminated from the competition after receiving the fewest votes in the first round of televoting. In the second round, Cookies 'N' Beans were eliminated after received the fewest votes. The remaining four acts progressed to the duels.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13241|title=Sweden: Another two acts chosen for the national final|last=Klier|first=Marcus|date=2009-02-14|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2009-02-14}}{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1444691/mans_z_och_h_e_a_t_till_globen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1444691 |title=Måns Z och H.E.A.T till Globen |date=2009-02-14 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613004725/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1444691/mans_z_och_h_e_a_t_till_globen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1444691 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !rowspan="2"|# !rowspan="2"|Artist !rowspan="2"|Song

border-style: solid;border-color:black;"|  |- | height=6| |} 812,874 votes were cast for the second semi-final, a new record for any semi-final, with an increase of over 60,000 votes over last year's second semi-final. 1,269,806.50kr was donated to SVT's ''Radiohjälpen'' due to the large number of calls made on the night. ===Semi-final 3=== [[File:Melodifestivalen 2009.JPG|thumb|300px|Host [[Petra Mede]] during the third semi-final in [[Leksand]].]] The third semi-final was held on 21 February at the [[Ejendals Arena]] in [[Leksand]]. The first act on stage was [[Velvet (singer)|Velvet]], performing "[[The Queen (Velvet song)|The Queen]]". Velvet begins the performance in a gigantic pink dress, which opens up to reveal seven backing dancers in [[Commedia dell'arte]] dress. The stage was filled with smoke and shone pink. Second on stage was Rigo & The Topaz Sound feat. Red Fox with "I Got U". The song mixes [[Motown]] with modern elements, with all on stage dressed as such, wearing red and white suits and dresses. The stage was filled to capacity, with two lead singers, a pianist, drummer, guitarist, saxophonist and two female backing singers. The next act on stage was [[Molly Sandén]], who represented [[Sweden in the Junior Eurovision Song Contest]] in [[Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2006|2006]] with "Det finaste någon kan få". At Melodifestivalen she performed "Så vill stjärnorna" (We will have the stars). The 16-year-old performed the emotional ballad alone on stage, dressed in an elegant white dress, while screens in the background showed shining stars. The fourth act on stage was boyband [[E.M.D.]], performing "[[Baby Goodbye (E.M.D. song)|Baby Goodbye]]". The boys performed the energetic pop song in black tuxedos, and were joined on stage by four male backing dancers, also in black tuxedos.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13328|title=Live: Melodifestivalen third semi final|last=Floras|first=Stella|date=2009-02-21|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2009-02-21}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5182|title=Live from Leksand, report and results|last=van Tongeren|first=Mario|date=2009-02-21|publisher=''Oikotimes''|accessdate=2009-02-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224153732/http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5182|archivedate=2009-02-24|df=}}''Melodifestivalen 2009: Semi-final 3''. ''[[Sveriges Television]]'' (2009-02-21). Retrieved on 2009-02-21. Next on stage was [[Mikael Rickfors]] with "Du vinner över mig!" (You win me over!), a rock/pop song. Rickfors, dressed in a black and navy blue suit, was joined by an all-female backing band, dressed in black, while blue light filled the stage during the performance. Maja Gullstrand was next on stage, singing "Här för mig själv" (Here for myself). Gullstrand performed in a short white dress, and joined on stage by a group of backing dancers in minimalistic black suits and dresses, while colourful bubbles were shown on the backing screens. The penultimate act of the night was [[Sofia (Swedish singer)|Sofia]] with "[[Alla (song)|Alla]]" (Άλλα; Other), an ethno pop song with rock elements, performed in [[Greek language|Greek]]. Sofia, dressed in black, was joined on stage by two male violinists in black, as well as four women playing large transparent drums on stage, while the stage was filled with colourful light. The last act on stage was three-time participants [[BWO (band)|BWO]] performing "You're Not Alone", a sentimental electric ballad. The band, consisting of [[Martin Rolinski]] on vocals and [[Alexander Bard]] and [[Marina Schiptjenko]] on keyboards, were dressed in futuristic space suits in grey and yellow. They were joined on stage by five backing dancers, also dressed in the same styles, using light skicts during the performance. Images of comets passing throung space were also shown on the backing screens. Velvet, Sofia and Maja Gullstrand were knocked out after the first round of televoting, receiving the fewest votes. Mikael Rickfors joined them after the second round, also receiving the fewest votes. The four remaining acts passed through to the duels.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13326|title=Sweden: Another two acts chosen for the final|last=Klier|first=Marcus|date=2009-02-21|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2009-02-21}}{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1453212/e_m_d_och_molly_sanden_till_globen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1453212 |title=E.M.D. och Molly Sandén till Globen |date=2009-02-21 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-02-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613004746/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1453212/e_m_d_och_molly_sanden_till_globen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1453212 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !rowspan="2"|# !rowspan="2"|Artist !rowspan="2"|Song

Red Fox battled E.M.D., with E.M.D. winning the more votes and progressing to the final. BWO took on Molly Sandén for the place in the final as well, with Sandén coming out on top.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1940|title=Sweden: Globen awaits Molly Sandén and E.M.D!|last=Schacht|first=Andreas|date=2009-02-21|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2009-02-21}} {| border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 style="font-size: 90%; margin:1em auto 1em auto;" | height=6| | align="center" colspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" bgcolor="#f2f2f2"|Duels | colspan="2"| | align="center" colspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" bgcolor="#f2f2f2"|To Final |- | height=6| | width=300|  | width=60|  | width=20|  | width=25|  | width=240|  |- | height=6| | colspan="2" rowspan="2"|  | rowspan="4" style="border-width:0 0 1px 0; border-style: solid;border-color:black;"|  | rowspan="7" style="border-width:0 0 1px 0; border-style: solid;border-color:black;"|  |- | height=6| |- | height=6| | rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" bgcolor="silver" |  Rigo & The Topaz Sound feat. Red Fox - "I Got You" | rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" bgcolor="silver" align="center"|  39 124 |- | height=6| | colspan="2" rowspan="2"|  |- | height=6| | rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" bgcolor="gold" |  '''[[E.M.D.]] - "Baby Goodbye"''' | rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" bgcolor="gold" align="center"|  '''116 034''' | rowspan="6" style="border-width:2px 3px 1px 0; border-style: solid;border-color:black;"|  |- | height=6| | rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" bgcolor="gold" |  '''[[E.M.D.]] - "Baby Goodbye"''' |- | height=6| | colspan="2" rowspan="2"|  |- | height=6| | rowspan="11" style="border-width:2px 0 0 0; border-style: solid;border-color:black;"|  | rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" bgcolor="gold" |  '''[[Molly Sandén]] - "Så vill stjärnorna"''' |- | height=6| | rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" bgcolor="silver" |  [[BWO (band)|BWO]] - "You're Not Alone" | rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" bgcolor="silver" align="center"|  66 108 |- | height=6| | colspan="2" rowspan="3"| |- | height=6| | rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" bgcolor="gold" |  '''[[Molly Sandén]] - "Så vill stjärnorna"''' | rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" bgcolor="gold" align="center"|  '''85 886''' | rowspan="2" style="border-width:2px 0 0 0; border-style: solid;border-color:black;"|  |- | height=6| |} 691,238 votes were cast for the third semi-final, with 1,053,643kr being donated to SVT's ''Radiohjälpen'' from the calls. ===Semi-final 4=== The fourth and final semi-final was held on 28 February at the new [[Malmö Arena]] in [[Malmö]]. [[File:Sarah Dawn Finer.JPG|thumb|left|150px|[[Sarah Dawn Finer]] performing "Moving On".]] First on stage was [[Agnes Carlsson|Agnes]] with "[[Love Love Love (Agnes song)|Love Love Love]]", a Europop song. Anges performed in a skin-tight gold outfit, and was joined on stage by six backing dancers in black and gold. Agnes began her performance on a lit catwalk, while a moving city skyline was shown on the backing screens. Confetti also fell towards the end of the song. The [[Star Pilots]] were next on stage with "Higher". The band were dressed as pilots, and in the background images of airplanes, runways and airplane wheels were shown. The third act on stage was [[Susanne Alfvengren]] with the emotional ballad "Du är älskad där du går" (You are loved where you go). Alfvengren performed alone on stage, dressed in a long purple dress, while the stage was lighted by shining lights on the backing screens. Two former Eurovision artists were next on stage, with [[Anna Sahlene]] and [[Maria Haukaas Storeng]] pairing up to perform "Killing Me Tenderly". The duo, dressed in silver dresses, were joined by five female backing dancers who created silouhettes of themselves on the backing screens. The LED screens in the background showed flames and lava, with red light pouring onto the stage.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13398|title=Live: fourth semi final in Sweden|last=Klier|first=Marcus|date=2009-02-28|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2009-02-28}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5252 |title=Live from Malmö, the 4th Melodifestivalen semifinal; results |last=Backfish |first=Emma |date=2009-02-28 |publisher=''Oikotimes'' |accessdate=2009-02-28 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}''Melodifestivalen 2009: Semi-final 4''. ''[[Sveriges Television]]'' (2009-02-28). Retrieved on 2009-02-28. Next on stage was the Thorleifs with "[[Sweet Kissin' in the Moonlight]]", a nostalgic rock/pop/[[schlager]] entry. The band were dressed in matching white suits, with the lead singer in black. The five-piece band were later joined by three backing dancers in 1950s clothing, with red polka dot dresses and red braces. [[Sarah Dawn Finer]] followed with "Moving On", dressed in red. The performance began with a sunrise being shown on the LED screens, with wind machines introduced at the chorus. Two male backing dancers in white joined afterwards, followed by three feamle backing singers, also in white. Finer was then raised by an automatic lift towards the side of the stage. The penultimate act was boyband Next 3 with "Esta noche" (Tonight), sung in Swedish, with the chorus in Spanish. The trio were joined by three female backing dancers and two fire jugglers for their performance, while the screens showed urban scenes. The final act was wild card [[Malena Ernman]] with opera song "[[La voix]]" (The voice), performed in English and [[French language|French]] during the chorus. Ernman, dressed in a long black dress, was joined by seven backing dancers in black and white, who performed with black shining masks towards the end. the backing screens and floor were coloured in solid colours, with green and purple in the verses and white and blue during the chorus. Next 3, Anna Sahlene & Maria Haukaas Storeng and Susanne Alfvengren were knocked out after the first round of televoting, receiving the fewest votes. They were joined by the Thorleifs who received the fewest votes during the second round. The remaining four acts passed to the duels.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13401|title=Sweden: Another two acts chosen for the final|last=Klier|first=Marcus|date=2009-02-28|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2009-02-28}}{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1462003/agnes_och_malena_till_finalen_i_globen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1462003 |title=Agnes och Malena till finalen i Globen |date=2009-02-28 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-02-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613005048/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1462003/agnes_och_malena_till_finalen_i_globen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1462003 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !rowspan="2"|# !rowspan="2"|Artist !rowspan="2"|Song

border-style: solid;border-color:black;"|  |- | height=6| |} A total of 639,928 televotes were cast during the final semi-final, with a total of 1,122,841.50kr donated to the ''Radiohjälpen'' appeal. ===Second Chance=== [[File:Star Pilots.JPG|thumb|200px|[[Star Pilots]] performing "Higher".]] The ''Andra Chansen'' (Second Chance) heat was held on 7 March at the [[Himmelstalundshallen]] in [[Norrköping]]. Eight songs competed for a second chance to reach the final, featuring the losing songs from the knockout rounds in the previous four heats. For the first round eight songs battled to progress to the second round. The Scotts from [[#Semi-final 1|semi-final 1]] and [[Sarah Dawn Finer]] from [[#Semi-final 4|semi-final 4]] were the first songs to battle – the winner was Sarah Dawn Finer with "Moving On". [[#Semi-final 2|Semi-final 2]]'s [[Lili & Susie]] and [[#Semi-final 3|semi-final 3]]'s [[BWO (band)|BWO]] were the next duo to battle each other – Lili & Susie edged ahead of BWO to progress to the next round. [[Amy Diamond]] and the [[Star Pilots]] battled against each other, with the Star Pilots coming out on top, while Rigo & The Topaz Sound feat. Red Fox competed against [[Caroline af Ugglas]], with af Ugglas progressing.{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13454 |title=Live: Second chance round in Sweden |last=Klier |first=Marcus |date=2009-03-07 |publisher=ESCToday |accessdate=2009-03-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090309193850/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13454 |archivedate=2009-03-09 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5286 |title=Live from Norrköping, the second chance round of Melodifestivalen |last=Backfish |first=Emma |date=2009-03-07 |publisher=''Oikotimes'' |accessdate=2009-03-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090319145116/http://oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5286 |archivedate=2009-03-19 |df= }}''Melodifestivalen 2009: Second Chance''. ''[[Sveriges Television]]'' (2009-03-07). Retrieved on 2009-03-07. The second round decided the two Second Chance qualifiers for the final: Lili & Susie battled against Sarah Dawn Finer, while the Star Pilots competed against Caroline af Ugglas. The final winners of Second Chance were Sarah Dawn Finer with "Moving On", and Caroline af Ugglas with "Snälla, snälla".{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13455|title=Sweden: Last three acts chosen for the final|last=Klier|first=Marcus|date=2009-03-07|publisher=ESCToday|accessdate=2009-03-07}}{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1471740/sarah_caroline_och_sofia_till_finalen_i_globen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1471740 |title=Sarah, Caroline och Sofia till finalen i Globen |date=2008-03-07 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2008-03-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613005109/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1471740/sarah_caroline_och_sofia_till_finalen_i_globen?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1471740 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1978|title=Sarah Dawn Finer, Caroline af Ugglas and Sofia to Globen!|last=Schacht|first=Andreas|date=2009-03-07|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2009-03-07}} In total 939,222 votes were cast for the Second Chance round. {| border=0 cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 style="font-size: 90%; border-style: solid;border-color:black;"|  |- | height=6| | rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" | Rigo & The Topaz Sound feat. Red Fox - "I Got U" | rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" align="center"| 49 543 |- | height=6| | colspan="2" rowspan="3"| |- | height=6| | rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" bgcolor="gold"| '''[[Caroline af Ugglas]] - "Snälla, snälla"''' | rowspan="2" style="border:1px solid #aaa;" align="center" bgcolor="gold"| '''100 860''' | rowspan="2" style="border-width:2px 0 0 0; border-style: solid;border-color:black;"|  |- | height=6| |} ==International Jury== [[File:Caroline Af Ugglas.JPG|thumb|left|150px|[[Caroline af Ugglas]], performing "Snälla snälla".]] The international jury had the task of selecting a song from each heat which they think was the most suitable for the Eurovision Song Contest. The jury were only able to pick songs that had not passed to the final. If they pick a song which qualifies to the final through the Second Chance round, that song became ineligible for the jury's choice. The international jury were also given the right to vote during the final of the contest, becoming the 12th jury, alongside the 11 regional juries. The first song to receive the international jury wildcard was [[Caroline af Ugglas]], who passed to Second Chance from the Gothenburg heat on 7 February with "Snälla, snälla". [[Amy Diamond]] was the second qualifier, however, shortly after the show it was rumoured that the announcement of Diamond as the jury choice was incorrect, and that the true choice was [[Jennifer Brown (singer)|Jennifer Brown]], who had placed 7th in the televote. This rumour however was revealed to be false by SVT, with Diamond as the correct choice.{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5127 |title=False rumours about Melodifestivalen error |last=van Tongeren |first=Mario |date=2009-02-15 |publisher=''Oikotimes'' |accessdate=2009-07-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090331225536/http://oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5127 |archivedate=2009-03-31 |df= }} The Leksand wildcard selected was [[Sofia (Swedish singer)|Sofia]] with "Alla". This song was the only jury wilcard selected that failed to qualify to Second Chance, coming 7th in the televote.{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5213 |title=A Swedish who sings in Greek |last=Fantis |first=Giorgos |date=2009-02-21 |publisher=''Oikotimes'' |accessdate=2009-02-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228101641/http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5213 |archivedate=2009-02-28 |df= }} The final wildcard, coming from the Malmö qualifier, was [[Sarah Dawn Finer]] with "Moving On", another Second Chance qualifier. As Sarah Dawn Finer and Caroline af Ugglas had qualified from the Second Chance round to the final this made them ineligible to be chosen for the international jury qualifier. This left two songs left to compete for the 11th final place: either [[Amy Diamond]], who had already been knocked out of Second Chance in the first round, or [[Sofia (Swedish singer)|Sofia]]. The final choice by the jury was for Sofia with "Alla". ===Members of the International Jury=== '''The following people were members of the international jury:'''{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=79613&a=1481193&lid=senasteNytt_979119&lpos=rubrik_1481193 |title=Den internationella juryn |date=2009-03-14 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-10-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090526215211/http://svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=79613&a=1481193&lid=senasteNytt_979119&lpos=rubrik_1481193 |archivedate=2009-05-26 |df= }} *Bruno Berberes (France) - ''President'' - Head of the French Eurovision delegation *Natalia Brasnuev ([[Moldova]]) - President of [[OGAE]] Moldova *[[Fred Bronson]] (United States) - Musical journalist/writer *Alessandro Capicchioni ([[San Marino]]) - TV program editor, Head of Delegation for San Marino *Damir Perić ([[Serbia]]) - ESC fan *Thomas Lundin (Finland) - TV presenter, singer *Yurii Nikitin ([[Ukraine]]) - Music company director *[[Alexandros Panayi]] ([[Cyprus]]) - Singer *[[Marija Šerifović]] ([[Serbia]]) - Singer, winner of [[Eurovision Song Contest 2007|ESC 2007]] *Maryna Skomorokhova ([[Ukraine]]) - Senior Account Manager for CFC, Ukraine's Eurovision sponsor *Anastasiya Tihanovich ([[Belarus]]) - Singer, executive producer of [[belarus in the Eurovision Song Contest 2009|EuroFest 2009]] *Barry Viniker (United Kingdom) - Marketing and communications, managing director of [http://www.esctoday.com/ esctoday.com] ===Jury Selections=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! ''(Please, please)'' || Second Chance qualifier || Ineligible |- | Skellefteå || [[Amy Diamond]] || "It's My Life" || Second Chance qualifier || Not chosen |-bgcolor="gold" | Leksand || [[Sofia (Swedish singer)|Sofia]] || "[[Alla (song)|Alla]]"
''(Other)'' || 7th || '''Chosen''' |-bgcolor="#D3D3D3" | Malmö || [[Sarah Dawn Finer]] || "Moving On" || Second Chance qualifier || Ineligible |- |} ==Final== The final of Melodifestivalen 2009 was held at the [[Ericsson Globe|Globen]] arena in [[Stockholm]] on 14 March 2009. The run-up to the final began shortly after the [[#Second Chance|Second Chance]] round had been completed, when the running order for the final was revealed – [[#Semi-final 2|semi-final 2]] qualifier [[Måns Zelmerlöw]] would open proceeding on the night, while [[#Semi-final 4|semi-final 4]] qualifier and wild card [[Malena Ernman]] would finish the performances for the evening.{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1471775/startordning_melodifestivalfinalen_2009?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1471775 |title=Startordning Melodifestivalfinalen 2009 |date=2009-03-08 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-07-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613005125/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1471775/startordning_melodifestivalfinalen_2009?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1471775 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} The favourites to win the contest were Zelmerlöw and Ernman, with the [[#International Jury|international jury]] wild card [[Sofia (Swedish singer)|Sofia]] predicted as most likely to finish last, according to [[bookmaker]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5328 |title=Malena and Måns favourites across the board |last=Fisher |first=Luke |date=2009-03-14 |publisher=''Oikotimes'' |accessdate=2009-07-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418055429/http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5328 |archivedate=2009-04-18 |df= }} Måns Zelmerlöw took the stage first on the night, repeating his performance from the semi-final of "[[Hope & Glory (song)|Hope & Glory]]". Second Chance qualifier [[Caroline af Ugglas]] followed Zelmerlöw on stage with "Snälla snälla", repeating her emotional performance alone on stage. [[Agnes Carlsson|Agnes]] was next on stage, performing "[[Love Love Love (Agnes song)|Love Love Love]]", now with a new hairstyle, but no major changes were made to the performance since the semi-final. [[H.E.A.T]] followed with their rock song "1000 Miles", who were then followed by [[Emilia Rydberg|Emilia]] with "You're My World".{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13517 |title=Live: National final in Sweden |last=Klier |first=Marcus |date=2009-03-14 |publisher=ESCToday |accessdate=2009-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090317055628/http://esctoday.com/news/read/13517 |archivedate=2009-03-17 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5331|title=Live from Stockholm, Melodifestivalen Final|last=Fisher|first=Luke|date=2009-03-14|publisher=''Oikotimes''|accessdate=2009-03-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090317072517/http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=5331|archivedate=2009-03-17|df=}}''Melodifestivalen 2009: Final''. ''[[Sveriges Television]]'' (2009-03-14). Retrieved on 2009-03-14. Two-time participant [[Alcazar (band)|Alcazar]] were the sixth act to take the stage at Globen, performing disco/pop number "[[Stay the Night (Alcazar song)|Stay the Night]]", who were followed by the second Second Chance qualifier [[Sarah Dawn Finer]], performing "Moving On". Boyband [[E.M.D.]], now performing in white tuxedos, were eighth on stage with "[[Baby Goodbye (E.M.D. song)|Baby Goodbye]]". International jury selection [[Sofia (Swedish singer)|Sofia]] followed on stage, singing the Greek ethno number "[[Alla (song)|Alla]]". She was followed by 16-year-old [[Molly Sandén]] with "[[Så vill stjärnorna]]", and finally by [[Malena Ernman]] with "[[La voix]]". At the final vote [[Malena Ernman]] was the winner: despite only coming 8th in the jury vote, she was able to win the televote and guarantee victory with "[[La voix]]". The runner-up was Caroline af Ugglas with "Snälla snälla", while [[E.M.D.]] came third with "[[Baby Goodbye (E.M.D. song)|Baby Goodbye]]". The winner of the jury vote was [[Måns Zelmerlöw]] with "[[Hope & Glory (song)|Hope & Glory]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13518 |title=Sweden: Malena Ernman to Eurovision |last=Klier |first=Marcus |date=2009-03-14 |publisher=ESCToday |accessdate=2009-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090317055636/http://esctoday.com/news/read/13518 |archivedate=2009-03-17 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=2001|title=Sweden: Malena Ernman to Moscow!|last=Schacht|first=Andreas|date=2009-03-14|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=2009-03-14}}{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1481204/malena_ernman_vann_melodifestivalen_2009?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1481204 |title=Malena Ernman vann Melodifestivalen 2009 |date=2009-03-14 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613005142/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1481204/malena_ernman_vann_melodifestivalen_2009?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1481204 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} 1,748,970 votes were received during the final, with a total of 3,457,434.50kr being donated to SVT's ''Radiohjälpen'' appeal. 3,592,000 people watched the final on SVT, however over 10 million watched the show live on SVT's online video on demand service [[SVT Play]].{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=79613&a=1482287&lid=senasteNytt_979119&lpos=rubrik_1482287 |title=Över tio miljoner Play-starter för Melodifestivalen 2009 |date=2009-03-16 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-03-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090318235401/http://svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=79613&a=1482287&lid=senasteNytt_979119&lpos=rubrik_1482287 |archivedate=2009-03-18 |df= }} {| ''(Other)'' || [[Dimitri Stassos]] (m), Henrik Wikström (m), Irini Michas (m), Nina Karolidou (l) || 12 || — || 12 || 10th |- | 10 || [[Molly Sandén]] || "Så vill stjärnorna"
''(So the stars want)'' || [[Bobby Ljunggren]] (m), Marcos Ubeda (m), [[Ingela Forsman|Ingela "Pling" Forsman]] (l) || 2 || — || 2 || 11th |- bgcolor="#FFD700" | '''11''' || '''[[Malena Ernman]]''' || '''"[[La voix (song)|La Voix]]"''' || '''[[Fredrik Kempe]] (m & l), [[Malena Ernman]] (l)''' || '''38''' || '''144''' || '''182''' || '''1st''' |} ===Voting=== The voting in the final was made up of both televoting/SMS voting and jury voting. 12 juries – 11 regional juries from around Sweden, along with the international jury – gave 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 and 12 points to their favourite songs. This was joined by televoting, with the total votes being converted into a set number of points – 12, 24, 48, 72, 96, 120 and 144 points were given to the most-popular songs of the total televote from around Sweden. The International jury results were announced immediately after all the entries were performed, while the televoting was still taking place. These results were announced on stage by [[Eurovision Song Contest 2007]] winner and International Jury member [[Marija Šerifović]]. [[Måns Zelmerlöw]] was the favourite with the juries, receiving a total of 96 points. [[Sarah Dawn Finer]] came second with the juries, gaining 75 points, while [[Alcazar (band)|Alcazar]] came third with 67. However the televoting completely contradicted this, with the televoting favourite [[Malena Ernman]] coming only eighth in the jury vote, while runner-up [[Caroline af Ugglas]] came only 5th in the jury. ====Juries==== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Song !International

"La voix" || 38 || {{lsc11amp|322.657}} (18.4%) || '''144''' || '''182''' |} ==Marcel Bezençon Awards 2009== {{main|Marcel Bezençon Awards}} The Marcel Bezençon Awards honour the best competing songs in the final of Melodifestivalen. First awarded at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2002|2002 Eurovision Song Contest]], they have been awarded at Melodifestivalen since [[Melodifestivalen 2005|2005]]. The awards were founded by [[Christer Björkman]] (Sweden's representative in the [[1992 Eurovision Song Contest]] and Melodifestivalen producer since [[Melodifestivalen 2002|2002]]) and Richard Herrey (member of the [[Herreys]], [[Eurovision Song Contest 1984]] winner from Sweden), and are named after the creator of the [[Eurovision Song Contest]], [[Marcel Bezençon]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gylleneskor.se/marcelbezenconaward/en|title=Marcel Bezençon Award - an introduction|work=[[Gylleneskor]]|accessdate=2009-06-02}} The awards are divided into 3 categories: *'''Press Award''' - Given to the best entry as voted on by the accredited media and press during the event. *'''Artistic Award''' - Presented to the best artist as voted on by former winners of Melodifestivalen. *'''Composer Award''' - A jury consisting of the participating composers vote for the best and most original composition. The 2009 Melodifestivalen awards were announced before the final of the contest:{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1531032/vinnare_av_marcel_bezencon_award_2009?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1531032 |title=Vinnare av Marcel Bezençon Award 2009 |date=2009-03-14 |publisher=[[Sveriges Television]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613005153/http://svt.se/2.79613/1.1531032/vinnare_av_marcel_bezencon_award_2009?lid=senasteNytt_741385&lpos=rubrik_1531032 |archivedate=2011-06-13 |df= }} *The Press Award was given to [[Caroline af Ugglas]] with "Snälla snälla"; *The Artistic Award was given to [[Sarah Dawn Finer]] with "Moving On"; *And the Composer Award was awarded to [[Emilia Rydberg]] and [[Figge Boström|Fredrik "Figge" Boström]] with "You're My World", performed by Emilia. ==Chart success== A large number of songs from Melodifestivalen were able to chart in the Swedish singles chart – [[Sverigetopplistan]] – with two songs managing to peak at #1. The first song to reach #1 in Sweden was [[Shirley Clamp]]'s "Med hjärtat fyllt av ljus". The song, which was knocked out of the first semi-final, was released shortly afterwards, entering the charts on 20 February at #25. The song rose in the charts, and reached #1 on 6 March, the day before the Second Chance round.[http://www.swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Shirley+Clamp&titel=Med+hj%E4rtat+fyllt+av+ljus&cat=s Shirley Clamp - "Med hjärtat fyllt av ljus"] ''swedishcharts.com'' The second song to reach #1 from Melodifestvalen was [[E.M.D.]]'s "[[Baby Goodbye (E.M.D. song)|Baby Goodbye]]". The song, released after the fourth semi-final per Melodifestivalen rules, entered at #3, before rising to #1 on 13 March, the day before the final, entering the final as #1. The song stayed at #1 for two weeks.[http://www.swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=E%2EM%2ED%2E&titel=Baby+Goodbye&cat=s E.M.D. - "Baby Goodbye"] ''swedishcharts.com'' Four further songs peaked at #2 of the Sverigetopplistan, [[Alcazar (band)|Alcazar]]'s "[[Stay the Night (Alcazar song)|Stay the Night]]",[http://www.swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Alcazar&titel=Stay+The+Night&cat=s Alcazar - "Stay the Night"] ''swedishcharts.com'' [[Caroline af Ugglas]]' "Snälla snälla",[http://www.swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Caroline+Af+Ugglas&titel=Sn%E4lla+sn%E4lla&cat=s Caroline af Ugglas - "Snälla snälla"] ''swedishcharts.com'' [[Måns Zelmerlöw]]'s "Hope & Glory",[http://www.swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=M%E5ns+Zelmerl%F6w&titel=Hope+%26+Glory&cat=s Måns Zelmerlöw - "Hope & Glory"] ''swedishcharts.com'' and winner [[Malena Ernman]] with "[[La voix]]".[http://www.swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Malena+Ernman&titel=La+voix&cat=s Malena Ernman - "La voix"] ''swedishcharts.com'' [[H.E.A.T]] and [[Sarah Dawn Finer]] peaked at #3 with "1000 Miles" and "Moving On" respectively,[http://www.swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=H%2EE%2EA%2ET%2E&titel=1000+Miles&cat=s H.E.A.T - "1000 Miles"] ''swedishcharts.com''[http://www.swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Sarah+Dawn+Finer&titel=Moving+On&cat=s Sarah Dawn Finer - "Moving On"] ''swedishcharts.com'' while [[Agnes Carlsson|Agnes]] peaked at #4 with "[[Love Love Love (Agnes song)|Love Love Love]]"[http://www.swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Agnes&titel=Love+Love+Love&cat=s Agnes - "Love Love Love"] ''swedishcharts.com'' and [[Star Pilots]] and [[Lili & Susie]] peaked at #6 with "Higher" and "Show Me Heaven".[http://www.swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Star+Pilots&titel=Higher&cat=s Star Pilots - "Higher"] ''swedishcharts.com''[http://www.swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Lili+%26+Sussie&titel=Show+Me+Heaven&cat=s Lili & Susie - "Show Me Heaven"] ''swedishcharts.com'' Follow-up albums by many of the artists also did well in the Swedish albums chart: Måns Zelmerlöw's ''[[MZW]]'', Sarah Dawn Finer's ''Moving On'', Caroline af Ugglas' ''Så gör jag det igen'', and Malena Ernman's ''[[La Voix Du Nord]]'' all peaked at #1.[http://swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=M%E5ns+Zelmerl%F6w&titel=MZW&cat=a Måns Zelmerlöw - MZW] ''swedishcharts.com''[http://swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Sarah+Dawn+Finer&titel=Moving+On&cat=a Sarah Dawn Finer - Moving On] ''swedishcharts.com''[http://swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Caroline+Af+Ugglas&titel=S%E5+g%F6r+jag+det+igen&cat=a Caroline af Ugglas - Så gör jag det igen] ''swedishcharts.com''[http://swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Malena+Ernman&titel=La+voix+du+nord&cat=a Malena Ernman - La Voix Du Nord] ''swedishcharts.com'' ==See also== *[[Melodifestivalen]] *[[Eurovision Song Contest 2009]] *[[Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest 2009]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Melodifestivalen 2009}} *{{sv icon}} [http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen Official website] *{{sv icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20110612114028/http://svt.se/content/1/c8/01/05/68/94/Inbjudan%20till%20Melodifestivalen%202009.pdf Rules for Melodifestivalen 2009] {{Melodifestivalen}} [[Category:2009 Swedish television seasons]] [[Category:Melodifestivalen by year|2009]] [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest 2009 national selections]] [[Category:2009 in Swedish music]] [[Category:2009 song contests]] [[Category:February 2009 events in Europe]] [[Category:March 2009 events in Europe]] [[Category:2000s in Stockholm]] [[Category:2000s in Gothenburg]] [[Category:Events in Stockholm]] [[Category:Events in Gothenburg]] [[Category:Events in Norrköping]] [[Category:Events in Malmö]] [[Category:Events in Skellefteå]] [[Category:Events in Leksand]]
